Description: In many patients with cancer, metastatic disease emerges long after successful treatment of the primary tumor. This is so because persistent disseminated tumor cells (or DTCs) find residency at distant sites under a state of dormancy, only to awaken years or even decades afterwards and initiate metastases. This pause in cancer progression is both a clinical threat and a singular therapeutic window to prevent future metastases. This educational session aims at showcasing recently identified mechanisms by which the niche drives DTCs in or out of dormancy, including immune barriers to metastasis, epigenetic reprogramming and metabolic adaptations to the niche, and age-related changes in the niche that can reactivate dormant DTCs. These advances hold significant promise for therapeutic intervention in patients at risk of currently incurable metastatic disease.
